body:
## Problem

Netrw is huge and tries to do too many things without been great at nothing and
even though I'm actively maintain it neovim deserve a better option that takes
advantage of all it's features.

related issues: #32280 

## Solution

Create a minimal (264 LOC) minimal directory viewer that is fast, minimal and
that it's tries to do "the right thing :tm:" by default.

Features:
- Opens when trying to edit a directory (e.g. `:e .`)
- Tracks fs events with `uv.fs_event_t` so the directory list is always up to
  date with the filesystem (no more manual `<C-l>`)
- Preserves original/alternate buffers
- If no files are passed to `open()`, the directory of the current file is used
  (like `:Explore`)

## Open Questions

- Do I need to clean up watchers before closing neovim with a `VimLeave` autocmd?

## TODOs

- Write docstrings documentation
- Open multiple files via visual selection
- Better error handling for edge cases

comment_regular_data.body:
As one of those who've brought up `vim.ui.tree` in chat I'd like to point out that what I had in mind was a more generic abstraction not coupled to filesystem display.

Something more like textual [Tree](https://textual.textualize.io/widget_gallery/#tree) that can be used to display arbitrary data in tree shape with collapse/expand functionality and ideally also a way to retrieve the underlying data (lua table) from a given line.

This would then ideally support use-cases like:

- In core:
    - filesystem display
    - LSP: call hierarchies
    - LSP: symbols which can be tree-shaped
    - treesitter: `:InspectTree`
- In plugins
    - nvim-dap for example could use it for scopes and variable display - this has requirements like fetching children ad-hoc on expand instead of up-front, refreshing the view with new values while retaining the expansion levels or an action menu with arbitrary actions on the item under the cursor like set-variable, copy to register, etc.

> Something more like textual [Tree](https://textual.textualize.io/widget_gallery/#tree) that can be used to display arbitrary data in tree shape with collapse/expand functionality and ideally also a way to retrieve the underlying data (lua table) from a given line.

While I understand this point of view it seems an odd choice for the core to have something like this. It can put neovim in the position to ship more and more prepackaged components and I can see that we would end up on the same situation of the web all over again. Also for what I've seen in this [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TUzdcB_PFJA) justin goes against this type of direction by calling explicitly out [nui.nvim](https://github.com/MunifTanjim/nui.nvim) witch it offers a [tree component](https://github.com/MunifTanjim/nui.nvim/tree/main/lua/nui/tree) like the one you are suggesting.

I think for the core make sense to stick to a more traditional vim style ui mentality in witch we treat the buffer as this freely organized set of data (there is this [OG vim article](http://vimcasts.org/blog/2013/01/oil-and-vinegar-split-windows-and-project-drawer/) that I think represent this really well)).

But we are not traditional Vim; that's our whole raison d'être. 

We can absolutely build on top of that for a built in file manager UI, but _our_ way is to provide robust primitives first and foremost. 

(Also, traditional Vim has popups, so there.)

> But we are not traditional Vim; that's our whole raison d'être.
>
> We can absolutely build on top of that for a built in file manager UI, but our way is to provide robust primitives first and foremost.

Fair. But if you open this can of worms were do we finish? I for example would consider UI robust primitives also a way to easily display data as [table](https://github.com/MunifTanjim/nui.nvim/tree/main/lua/nui/table) and having a list like [menu](https://github.com/MunifTanjim/nui.nvim/tree/main/lua/nui/menu). 

> (Also, traditional Vim has popups, so there.)

Yes but it is just another way to display a buffer, it's like a split so I wouldn't consider it in the same category.
We'll burn that bridge when we cross it. For now, core considers a tree view high enough leverage. That does not prejudicate anything else.
Ok so I close this? I don't understand if it something of interest or not.

No, this is just guidance on how to implement this (bottom up), and specific to `vim.ui.tree`. A simple directory viewer (not file manager, at least for the MVP) is still desired (and may even just use a flat list of the current directory for the beginning).

> No, this is just guidance on how to implement this (bottom up).

Oh ok, so what should I do? Currently how this is implemented is like netrw so a directory is a flat list of files. 

Do I create this generic tree component and the directory viewer or there is someone else working on this tree component and I need to way until that is done?
Nobody is working on that, so go for it!

But I maybe would recommend splitting these into independent PRs (one for directory viewing and file opening from a flat list, one for a generic `vim.ui.tree`). 

Pro tip: keep your PRs as focused and atomic as possible; this prevents scope creep, review filibuster, and merge delays.

My opinion is that directory hijacking (as it's called https://github.com/lambdalisue/vim-fern-hijack) is prone to conflicts, so it should be done in plugin/{name}.lua rather than _defaults.lua and disabled with `g:loaded_xxx = 1`.

> But I maybe would recommend splitting these into independent PRs (one for directory viewing and file opening from a flat list, one for a generic vim.ui.tree).

Yes, I will keep this for the directory viewing and open a separate PR for the `vim.ui.tree` component

> Pro tip: keep your PRs as focused and atomic as possible; this prevents scope creep, review filibuster, and merge delays.

Thank you for the tip. Please don't judge my work by my netrw PRs I'm not really proud of those /j.
Nah, that's general advice we give all the time.

> While I understand this point of view it seems an odd choice for the core to have something like this. It can put neovim in the position to ship more and more prepackaged components and I can see that we would end up on the same situation of the web all over again. Also for what I've seen in this video justin goes against this type of direction by calling explicitly out nui.nvim witch it offers a tree component like the one you are suggesting.


If something should be in core or not is always a bit of a discussion and in the end a judgement call weighting different aspects like size and complexity, leverage and if already existing other components can benefit from it - or if it helps with other core functionality already on the radar. That seems to be the case here.

As for how to approach this: There's quite a bit of design space, so I suspect the bar for a final `vim.ui.tree` will be rather high and involve quite a bit of discussion. To lower the bar a bit it could be an option to go for a private `vim.ui._tree` for now that allows us to iterate on the API until we have something that's used in more than one place to confirm the design is working.

I'm not sure where to put the fs tree view that's built on top, maybe `vim.fs.tree()` or `vim.fs.inspect()`?
